title.narrative: Niger-Projet de Lutte contre l'Ensablement des Cuvettes

description.narrative: Projet de Lutte contre l'Ensablement des Cuvettes Oasiennes dans les Départements de Gouré et de Mainé-Soroa (PLECO)

title.narrative: Project for oasis micro-basin sand invasion control in the Gouré and Maïné-Soroa provinces
Lettre d'accord pour founiture de service

description.narrative: Projet de Lutte contre l’Ensablement des Cuvettes Oasiennes (PLECO)
seat of a second-order administrative division
populated place
Energy - policy, planning and administration
To protect the integrity of, and to improve the agro-sylvo-pastoral productivity of the micro-basin ecosystems in Goure' and Maine-Soroa provinces
1) Extension under dune protection and SLM practices [Note the latter part of indicator #1 is better captured under indicator #2]

comment.narrative: 305,000 ha under risk of sand invasion in Goure and Maine-Soroa provinces There is a serious sand invasion problem, exacerbated by non sustainable land and natural resource management practices; this problem is confirmed in development district plans.
7,510 ha protected in the micro-basins and on sylvo-pastoral spaces, as follows [Break-down below and includes both PLECO and partner financed interventions]:

Targets have been achieved in 2011 and have now been taken to another level. 13010 ha of dune stabilized the risk of sand invasion in Goure and Maine-Soroa provinces is considerably reduced. During the reporting period GEF and UNDP contributed directly to stabilize 360 ha of dune. And the Government of Niger contributed to stabilize 265 ha of dune.
0ha at project start.
PLECO: 4.410 ha
Target achieved during the reporting period. 4480 ha of dune stabilized by PLECO project supported by GEF
PADEL/ZR: 400 ha
N/A this indicator is closed since 2012
PADEL/DA: 750 ha
N/A this indicator is closed since 2012
PAGRN: 800 ha
N/A this indicator is closed since 2012
PIP2: 150 ha
N/A this indicator is closed since 2012
Other actors: 1,000 ha
Target achieved and surpassed. During the reporting period, 8333 ha of dune stabilized with the support of WFP and the Government of Niger.

description.narrative: 2) Improvement of agro-pastoral productivity in the 35 priority micro-basins and 5 sylvo-pastoral spaces that receive project support

comment.narrative: [See break-down below]
Productivity of agro-pastoral areas increases by at least 20% by the end of the project

Target achieved and surpassed. Productivity of agro-pastoral areas increases by at least 40%. The increasing of productivity is due to the fact that PLECO Project has built capacities of beneficiaries by the technic of RNA Assisted Natural Generation of some plants species on agro-pastoral areas.

description.narrative: 2a) Millet productivity in Goure:

comment.narrative: Goure: 261 kg / ha
Productivity of agro-pastoral areas increases by at least 20% by the end of the project
Target surpassed since 2014 Goure 530 kg/ha This result is due to the PLECO project effort and also to the contribution of others partners like FAO which provided improved seeds of millet

description.narrative: 2a) Millet productivity in Maine:

comment.narrative: Maine: 410 kg/ha
increase the productivity up to 20% from the base line

Target achieved, but with a drop since last year, which is considered normal, given expected variability in agricultural productivity from year to year for reasons that are external to the project. Maine 650 kg/ha. The improvement trends are though a result from the PLECO project's effort and also to the contribution of others partners, like FAO which disseminated improved seeds of millet. Comparatively to last year the productivity has decreased, but from all accounts this is due to a less than good the rain season. Such variations are expected. What matters is the long term trend and average. We have little data to compare, but note a general increase that can be attributed to the project.

description.narrative: 2b) Bean productivity:

comment.narrative: [See break-down below]
Productivity of agro-pastoral areas increases by at least 20% by the end of the project

Target achieved and slightly surpassed. Productivity of agro-pastoral areas increases by at least 15% due to the fact that farmers are trained in assisting the natural regeneration in 30 pilot sites. The practice of "assisted natural regeneration" is still one of the best practices that allow to improve the level of soils fertilization on project sites.

description.narrative: 2b) Bean productivity in Goure :

comment.narrative: Goure': 109 kg/ha.
increase the productivity up to 20% from the base line

Target achieved and slightly surpassed. Goure: 130 kg/ha. Bean productivity increased because the level of fertilization has improved and also the phenomenon of water and wind erosion has been significantly reduced due to the application of "assisted natural regeneration" technique.

description.narrative: 2b) Bean productivity in Maine:

comment.narrative: Maine: 70 kg/ha
increase the productivity up to 20% from the base line

Target achieved and slightly surpassed. Maine: 100 kg/ha. Bean productivity increased because the level of fertilization has improved and also the phenomenon of water and wind erosion has been significantly reduced due to the application of "assisted natural regeneration" technique.

description.narrative: Sustainable dune, land and ecosystem management activities are implemented at the grassroots level, covering approx. 7,510 ha of land.
3) Multi-annual operation plan for the protection of 35 strategic oasis micro-basins

comment.narrative: No operational plan available (meanwhile 580 and 287 villages are subjected to sand invasion in Maine-Soroa and Goure, respectively)
Operational plan for the protection of 35 strategic micro-basins is elaborated and validated during 1st year, and is implemented from 2nd year

Target closely achieved -- at 80% -- which is already considered a reasonable achievement. During the reporting period, PLECO project did not work with local action plans for the management of dunes. The project worked directly with the beneficiaries of the 60 pilot sites of land management by consolidating the efforts made previous years.

description.narrative: 4) Number of experimentation sites for best NRM practices in agro-pastoral systems installed

comment.narrative: Poor knowledge on best NRM practices in agro-pastoral systems
90 sites of pilot experimentation and demonstration of agricultural and pastoral good practices are installed with full population engagement

Target partially achieved -- at 63%. Though a target of 90 sites was not achieved, but 57 is considered a reasonable achievement under the circumstances. Only 60 demonstration sites of techniques for mechanical and biological fixation of dunes were operational during the reporting period; 30 demonstration sites of "assisted natural regeneration" technique. However this is still considered a major achievement. The target level was perhaps too ambitious.

description.narrative: Technical and managerial capacity of local stakeholders on dune, land and ecosystem management is strengthened in the 35 priority micro-basins
5) % of the population that acquire practical knowledge on sand, land and ecosystem management in the priority 35 micro-basins

comment.narrative: Poor awareness and training opportunities on SLM-related knowledge and practices and high levels of illiteracy

Target achieved in previous reporting periods and now consolidated. We highlight that 150 manuals of good practice on SLM were broadcast and 847 rural households have been trained and supervised in mechanical and biological fixation of dunes. 18600 people sensitized on sand, land and ecosystem management.

150 manuals of good practice on SLM were broadcast and 847 rural households have been trained and supervised in mechanical and biological fixation of dunes.
18600 people sensitized on sand, land and ecosystem management.

description.narrative: 6) Number of COFOs (land tenure committees) that improve dissemination of SLM practices and conflict resolution efforts

comment.narrative: COFOs show very weak capacities and poor functioning
At least half of the COFOs in the Goure and Maine-Soroa provinces improve their functioning thanks to the project

Target assumed achieved or on the way to being achieved, but generally not measurable (refer to 2013 reporting). The number of the COFOs established in the Goure and Maine-Soroa provinces did not change (13 strategic sites have been supported by local land commissions)

description.narrative: A monitoring system on sand dune and land degradation is established and implemented at national level and harmonized with SIP/TerrAfrica at regional level
7) Development of a sand dune and land degradation monitoring system (national scope) and application in Goure and Maine-Soroa provinces

comment.narrative: No such monitoring system exists
Sand dune and land degradation monitoring system is established through the new National Ecological Monitoring Centre

Target achieved. The CNSEE is managing the Database related to silting monitoring, piezometric groundwater monitoring, pluviometric situation and herbaceous vegetation monitoring. The annual monitoring report is available for each year.

description.narrative: 8) Number of projects and institutions that use the sand dune and land degradation indicators to plan/monitor their activities

comment.narrative: No indicators on sand dune and land degradation in place
At least 6 projects and/or institutions in the country use the new Centers indicators to plan/monitor activities

Target achieved. Twenty four (24) Local Natural Resource Management Committees (COGERNAT) have been established and trained to take over future GDT good practice experiment sites. A document of results capitalization on dunes and land degradation monitoring has been developed and made available for programs, projects, NGOs and other partners. Some projects of WFP and FAO are using the sand dune and land degradation indicators to plan their activities

description.narrative: An adaptive and lessons-sharing management system in place
9) Number of non-project stakeholders that visit project sites and activities for learning/replicating

comment.narrative: The Goure and Maine-Soroa provinces receive no much visits in relation to best practices or SLM innovations
At least 8 non-project stakeholders from other departments or abroad visit project sites to learn from projects best practices and innovations.
The target is already surpassed since last reporting period.

description.narrative: 10) Publications and IEC materials to disseminate sand, land and ecosystem management practices

comment.narrative: Few publications and IEC materials available
MTR and Final Evaluation rate publications and IEC materials produced as SATISFACTORY based on criteria of quantity, pedagogic quality and usage level.

Pending the TE to inform on target achievement, but assumed at a very good stand. 150 manuals of good practices on Land management have been produced and disseminated. Also the National Forum on fight against desertification held on 19 may 2015 in Niamey has allowed many people to understand sand, land and ecosystem management practices.

description.narrative: Objective: To expand Niger's managed protected area (PA) system within the Saharan biome by demonstrating effective approaches to PA management and establishing faunal migration corridors
1. Coverage of Saharan ecosystems in the National Protected Area System of Niger

comment.narrative:
(1a)
PA: 7,811,370 ha
(1b)
Corridor: 0 communes
(1a) PA: 16,093,326 ha (1b) Corridor: at least 20% of communes in the corridor

Target achieved and surpassed for the overall area and for the % of communes.
1a) PA: 17,711,370 ha On 06 March 2012, the Government of Niger formally decreed the "Reserve naturelle nationale de Termit et de Tin-Toumma (RNNTT)" to be a national nature and cultural reserve. With 9,700,000 ha, it is the largest single protected area in Africa. Target achieved and surpassed.
1b) Corridor: some 50% of communes in the corridor. Target achieved and surpassed

description.narrative: 2. Estimated populations of Addax in Nigerâ€™s Saharan biome are maintained stable

comment.narrative: Approx. 200
Approx. 200 (numbers maintained)

Target of numbers maintained is considered achieved. The estimated number of addax is still around 200 in the project zone. Meanwhile there are some exchanges with the international institutions (CMS, SCF) to carry out an aerial survey of the zone in near future. This will enable to have sufficient information on the fauna species within the Saharan biome.

Target met for most sub-indicators – no change since last year. From 30 june 2014 to 01 jully 2015, the MTR for the project is not yet realized; Hence, there is no sufficient elements to assess quantifiable progress towards target. However, as it the final evaluation is expected to start on september 2015, it gives the hope that this problem will be resolved.

description.narrative: 4. Improved financial sustainability of PA management agency, measured by increased scores of the Financial Sustainability Scorecard: Scorecard Component 1 - Legal and regulatory framework Scorecard Component 2 - Business planning Scorecard Component 1 - Tools for revenue generation

comment.narrative:
Comp 1:
39% - 32 out of 82 Comp 2:
1% - 1 out of 67 Comp 3:
4% - 2 out of 57 Total 17% - 35 out of 206

Target met for all components and for the total score. Comp 1:
42 %
Comp 2:
15%
Comp 3
7%
Total 23%
The increase of financial sustainability score is due to :National PA financing strategies, Training and support networks to enable PA managers to operate more cost-effectively, Setting and establishment of user fees across the PA system and Operational concessions within PAs

Not possible to assess quantifiable progress towards target, because there has been no recent applications of the scorecard which are specific to the Saharan Biome. The exercise should be vetted by the final evaluation planed in september 2015;

description.narrative: 5. Number of signed co-management agreements and local conventions

comment.narrative: 1 PA (Termit with Projet Antilopes SahÃ©lo-Sahariennes)
2 PAs and 20% of communities within the corridor
The documentation for the co management agreement is finalized. It is hoped that the first co-management agreements with municipalities will be developed shortly.

description.narrative: 2) Improved PA management effectiveness in 8.356 million hectares of new (RNN Termit 8.28 million ha) and existing (Gadabedji faunal reserve 76,000 ha) PAs
6. Improved PA management effectiveness at two pilot sites (Termit, Gadabedji) for general management and business planning, as measured by increases in the METT scores

comment.narrative: METT Scores (out of total possible of 102 points): Gadabedji: 32 points (31%) Termit: 54 points (53%)

Scores, expressed in percetage terms, increase by at least 10% in Termit and 30% in Gadabedji Indicatively: Gadabedji: 41 % Termit: 58% [***NOTE on LOGFRAME REVISION: because the METT total possible points have changed in the past and may change in the future, it is best to consider the targets as increases in the percentage results, rather than absolute numbers. ***]

Target achieved. Gadabedji: 58% Termit: 69% The increase in the level of score METT is due to the fact that there was some significant efforts in terms of training and capacity building of the project staff particularly those in charge of PA management. Also, the Government has appointed a huge number of Staff on the field to reinforce the protection and rehabilitation of natural resources as well as to boost biodiversity conservation within the Saharan biome. Moreover, the change occurred at the head of Termit Protected Management Unit brought a positive change as the activities implementation on the field (a permanent team is actually present on the field at Tesker monitoring conservation activities and preventing poaching within the saharian biome).

description.narrative: 7. Flora regeneration and stable/increasing population of selected faunal taxa (Addax in RNN Termit Tin Toumma and reintroduced species in Gadabedji and surrounding communities) show mitigation of direct threats to biodiversity

comment.narrative: RNN Termit Tin Toumma: ~ 200 Addax Gadabedji: flora: 14 herbal species in regression or extinct, detailed baseline t.b.d. upon project inception Dorcas gazelle: ~30 -60

RNN Termit Tin Toumma: ~ 200 Addax Gadabedji: flora: 14 herbal species in regression or extinct, detailed baseline t.b.d. upon project inception
Dorcas gazelle: ~30 -60
nothing to report

description.narrative: 8. Income generation from new value chains for local communities (pilot community hunting zones, ecotourism, local job creation etc.)

comment.narrative: To be identified during management and business plan elaboration for each zone

It is not possible to adequately inform the indicator, as a target was never set. However, we can report: During the reporting period 10 eco-guards have been recruited within the communes in order to contribute to the protection of natural resources.

description.narrative: 9. Number of communes in which community members benefit from sport hunting revenue in designated community hunting zones in the Gran Corridor [NOTE ON LOGFRAME CHANGE 2014] Indicator amended. Refer to 2014 reporting. For an explanation. Indicator # 9 was previous formulated as follows: [9. Number of communes in which community managers receive sport hunting revenue from community hunting areas contiguous to Gadabedji.]

comment.narrative: Not much progress made towards the target. During the year 2015, hunting activities are low and absents in some cases. Therefore, the communities have not benefited from the income generated by this activity. The contiguous communes to Gadabedji PA are e.g. not yet ready to support hunting activities. The objective, for now, is to create favorable conditions for the restoration of fauna species which have disappeared before.

description.narrative: 10. Number of reported and sanctioned violations of locally agreed natural resource use regulations in PA

comment.narrative:
Number of reports on "sanctions and violation of natural resources over the course of 1 year (2013 is the baseline): 10a) RNNTT (RÃ©serve Naturelle Nationale de Termit Tin Touma):
8 10b) GadabÃ©dji Fauna Reserve:
5
[NOTE ON LOGFRAME REVISION 2014] For the 2013 PIR the baseline and target for this indicator simply said â€œTBDâ€?. We have made progress in establishing a meaningful baseline for this indicator, and we can thereby also propose a target.

10a) no more than 4 10b) no more than 3 [NOTE ON LOGFRAME REVISION 2014] For the 2013 PIR the baseline and target for this indicator simply said â€œTBDâ€?. We have made progress in establishing a meaningful baseline for this indicator, and we can thereby also propose a target.

It is not possible to adequately inform the indicator, as a target was never set. Durind the reporting period 21 reports on "sanctions and violation of natural resources" have been produced in Gadabedji PA while 8 reports were registered in RNNTT PA.

description.narrative: 3) Strategically important natural habitats (key relevance for faunal migration and transhumance) within the Northern Niger Faunal Corridor of ~ 12.69 million hectares of Saharan landscape enjoy conservation through participatory sustainable land use systems and begin to re-establish conditions needed for future connectivity between the reserves of Gadabedji, Termit and AÃ¯r-TÃ©nÃ©rÃ©
11. Population of Addax (and other keystone species) is stable within Northern Niger Faunal Corridor and PA encompassed

comment.narrative: Addax: ~200 Other keystone species and baselines t.b.d. upon project inception
Addax: at least 300 Target values for other keystone species t.b.d. upon project inception

Not possible yet to inform the indicator, but important progress is being made towards it. But some missions carried out by NGO SCF have shown that the addax population is in regression because of anthrophic activities (oil exploration in South part of Bilma District).

description.narrative: 12. Critical habitats and key natural resources (grazing lands, water) for wild herbivores and transhumant livestock are stabilized/improved (verified through remote sensing and complemented by ground-truthing)

comment.narrative:
The following zones, containing critical habitats and key natural resources, have been identified in 2013/4. Parts of these zones could be proposed for having land-sue stabilised and the structure and functions of ecosystems improved through either rehabilitation or restoration. Zone Gadafawa-Taguedoufat (613189.4131 ha)
Zone centrale (419977.0564 ha)
Zone des dilias (279182.5861ha)
Zone des vallÃ©es (160779.8475 ha)
[NOTE ON LOGFRAME REVISION 2014] For the 2013 PIR the baseline for this indicator said â€œWill be identified during PDC elaboration / revisionâ€?. We have made progress in establishing a meaningful baseline for this indicator.

At least 30% of identified critical habitats are stabilized/improved
[NOTE ON LOGFRAME REVISION 2014] For the 2013 PIR the target for this indicator was 30%. We consider this a large area for habitat rehabilitation, but not necessarily for land-use stabilisation. We may adjust it in 2015 when the process is more advanced. We have made progress in establishing a meaningful target for this indicator, but more work is needed.

Progress made in identifying critical habitats, which is an initial, but essential step towards the target. The study on the "definition and the cartography of the Corridors, the identification of natural habitats" gave the opportunity to gather some information on the state of the critical habitats within the project zones The sites, which qualify as critical habitats containing key natural resources for wild herbivores and transhumant livestock are: Zone Gadafawa-Taguedoufat (613189.4131 ha) Zone centrale (419977.0564 ha) Zone des dilias (279182.5861ha) Zone des vallÃ©es (160779.8475 ha) Actions taken by the project to stabilize/improve critical habitats and key natural resources are: figtht against bush fires, dunes fixation and water points management.

description.narrative: 13. Number of PDC, PDGDRN, Schema d’amenagement foncier which integrates biodiversity conservation needs

comment.narrative: At least 20% of communes within the corridor [NOTE ON LOGFRAME 2014] We made a slight correction to the formulation here. It should read â€œcommuneâ€?, not â€œcommunityâ€?.

Making progress, but target not yet achieved. The Project Management Units carried out assessment activities within the communities during which some local structures for biodiversity conservation were identified and their needs in terms of capacity building were registered Also during the reporting period, 1 PAGC (Community Management Plan) and 1 PDC (Community Development Plan) have been developed in Gadabedji Forest reserve and three PDC (1 in Tesker, 1 in N\'Gourti and 1 in Tenhya) have been reviewed in order to integrate biodiversity conservation needs.

description.narrative: [***NOTE on LOGFRAME REVISION: indicator dropped, as it simply repeats indicator #8 and is hence redundant. ***] 14. Local income generation from sustainable biodiversity use (pilot community hunting zones)

comment.narrative: [***NOTE on LOGFRAME REVISION: indicator dropped.] 0 [no longer applicable]
To be identified during management plan elaboration for each zone
n/a - indicator dropped (refer to #8)

description.narrative: [***NOTE on LOGFRAME REVISION: indicator dropped, as it simply repeats indicator #9 and is hence redundant. ***] 15. Number of Corridor communes in which community managers receive sport hunting revenue from community hunting areas.

comment.narrative: [***NOTE on LOGFRAME REVISION: indicator dropped.] 0 [no longer applicable]
[***NOTE on LOGFRAME REVISION: indicator dropped.] 2 [no longer applicable]
n/a - indicator dropped (refer to #9)

description.narrative: [***NOTE on LOGFRAME REVISION: indicator dropped, as it is very similar to indicator #13 and is hence redundant. ***] 16. Number of commune/community level resource management structures with approved sets of rules governing resource access and use.

comment.narrative: [***NOTE on LOGFRAME REVISION: indicator dropped.] 0 [no longer applicable]
[***NOTE on LOGFRAME REVISION: indicator dropped.] 6 [no longer applicable]
n/a - indicator dropped (refer to #13)

comment.narrative:
Target A.3 Capacities of national Border Delegates system build/enhanced.
Target B.1: System of trend and incident reporting in place in selected border region(s), feeding regional knowledge management platform
Target B.2: Country Office Focal Points established to support coordination and further resource mobilisation in liaison with UNDP Dakar.
Target.C.1: Inclusive consultation processes established and documented in Liptakoa-Gourma region.
Target. C.2: Community-identified interventions funded in Lake Chad & Liptakoa-Gourma regions, improving trade and security interventions according to sub-indicators to be agreed.

Recrutement du staff (VNU nationale et chauffeur) et des prestataires internationaux et la mise en oeuvre effective du projet.
Mission régionale de cadrage pour la mise en œuvre du projet.
